When Tolkien wrote about the hobbits, he was referring to the gentlefolk of the English shires, who don’t realize the horrors that take place far away.

They were able to live their lives in peace and tranquility, but only because they were protected by the hard men of Gondor.

What happened to the nice man who was brutally murdered while walking his dog will happen to all of England if the tide of illegal immigration is not turned.

user.name: Gad Saad
user.description: Professor, Evolutionary Behavioral Scientist, Author. Opinions are mine alone. Retweets do not necessarily imply an endorsement.

tweets.text: I am increasingly confident that this idea could work

quoted.text:
Elon Musk came up with a pretty incredible idea during the Q3 Earnings Call, that no one is really talking about. 

His words: “Actually, one of the things I thought, if we've got all these cars that maybe are bored, while they're sort of, if they are bored, we could actually have a giant distributed inference fleet and say, if they're not actively driving, let's just have a giant distributed inference fleet.
At some point, if you've got tens of millions of cars in the fleet, or maybe at some point 100 million cars in the fleet, and let's say they had at that point, I don't know, a kilowatt of inference capability, of high-performance inference capability, that's 100 gigawatts of inference distributed with power and cooling taken, with cooling and power conversion taken care of. That seems like a pretty significant asset.”

So basically, each car has ~1 kilowatt of high-performance AI inference capability, Tesla wouldn’t need to build giant data centers — the fleet is the data center. 

Tesla could turn their entire fleet into a giant distributed inference network, spread across the world, powered by the batteries and AI in the car already.

Mind blown.

tweets.text: RT @amXFreeze: If you're in academia or an engineer trying to find information and you often end up on Wikipedia, you should definitely swi…

retweet.text:
If you're in academia or an engineer trying to find information and you often end up on Wikipedia, you should definitely switch to Grokipedia

Grokipedia offers information that is corrected and fact-checked by AI using a first-principles physics perspective, comes with the highest accuracy

On the other hand Wikipedia is written by humans and often carries inaccuracies and imprecise information

quoted.text:
Grokipedia correctly distinguishes applied physics from chemistry with its edit, while the Wikipedia article makes a significant academic error and is imprecise

Why: "Chemistry" and "Physics" are distinct, foundational sciences. Applied physics is a branch within physics

The Error: Listing "Chemistry" as a whole under applied physics is a broad categorization error. The specific overlap between the fields is "Chemical Physics," which is already listed separately

Grokipedia's edit to remove the redundant and incorrect "Chemistry" entry is the proper academic distinction

Please take a moment to vote your Tesla stock. It is super important. 

Control of Tesla could affect the future of civilization.

quoted.text:
Here are Tesla’s current five largest shareholders (excluding Elon Musk) and how they voted in last year’s ratification of Elon's 2018 pay package:

• Vanguard (holds $115B in $TSLA): For
• BlackRock ($95B): For
• State Street ($52B): Against
• Fidelity/Geode Capital ($30B): For
• JPMorgan Chase ($21B): For

Unlike last year’s ratification vote, Elon and Kimbal Musk can both participate in this year's 2025 CEO Performance Award plan vote due to Tesla's reincorporation to Texas (from Delaware).

BUT, we should not get complacent. Assume this vote is close and encourage everyone you know who is a $TSLA shareholder to vote. 8 days left.

tweets.text:
RT @MarioNawfal: 🚨GROKIPEDIA VS WIKIPEDIA: THE IVERMECTIN TRUTH TEST

Wikipedia treats ivermectin like toxic waste, framing everything thro…

retweet.text:
🚨GROKIPEDIA VS WIKIPEDIA: THE IVERMECTIN TRUTH TEST

Wikipedia treats ivermectin like toxic waste, framing everything through "misinformation" warnings. 

They even cite the FDA's "you're not a horse" tweet as if it's peer-reviewed science.

Grokipedia actually explains the drug's Nobel Prize-winning history, legitimate medical uses, and why researchers tested it for COVID. 

Failed studies get mentioned alongside successful ones... no agenda, just facts.

One site writes like reputation management for Big Pharma. 

The other writes like an encyclopedia should. 

Wikipedia turned from crowd-sourced knowledge into crowd-sourced propaganda.

The difference shows why alternative platforms are winning.

Source: @Grokipedia / Wikipedia Comparison

quoted.text:
🚨GROKIPEDIA VS WIKIPEDIA: CLIMATE CHANGE

Wikipedia’s Climate Change entry reads like a UN press release, loaded with activism, not analysis. 

It blames fossil fuels and human activity almost exclusively, quoting institutions like the WHO and Paris Agreement while minimizing uncertainty. 

Every sentence reinforces political urgency, not scientific nuance.

Grokipedia’s version, by contrast, takes a measured scientific tone, acknowledging warming trends and human contribution while noting natural variability, model uncertainty, and consensus overreach. 

It highlights that climate models often overestimate warming and that CO₂ also contributes to global greening.

One sells fear and politics.

The other delivers facts and context.

Sources: @Grokipedia , Wikipedia

AfD is dominating polls in…

retweet.text:
🇩🇪 ESTABLISHMENT PARTY: “WE’D RATHER LOSE EVERYTHING THAN TALK TO AfD” - MISSION ACCOMPLISHED

AfD is dominating polls in eastern Germany, 40% in Saxony-Anhalt, 38% in Mecklenburg-Vorpommern, and center-right party CDU is getting buried under its own strategy.

Chancellor Merz insists on clinging to the anti-AfD firewall, even as his own party quietly wonders if it’s time to stop lighting matches while standing in gasoline.

While the mainstream party waffles on how to handle AfD, voters see a clear contrast: one side calls for real border control, the other just calls press conferences.

AfD has made illegal immigration a central issue, meanwhile, the pro-establishment party still can’t decide if talking about it is racist or just inconvenient.

Behind closed doors, CDU leaders debate: stick to the script and sink, or blink and maybe survive?

One thing’s clear, AfD’s not waiting around for an invitation to win.

Source: La Gaceta de la Iberosfera

quoted.text:
🇩🇪 GERMANY'S AFD WANTS A BITCOIN VAULT 

Germany’s conservatives AfD just dropped a political grenade: 

A proposal to create a strategic Bitcoin reserve - the first of its kind in Europe.

The AfD motion calls for the German state to hold Bitcoin alongside gold and foreign currency reserves, framing it as a hedge against inflation and central bank chaos. 

Think Bundesbank meets blockchain.

If it passes, Germany would become the first major economy to treat crypto like sovereign wealth - a state-level bet that digital scarcity beats fiat policy. 

But this isn’t just economic strategy; it’s rebellion in ledger form.

The next great reserve race might not be for gold bars… but private keys.

Source: Coinfomania, Reuters

tweets.text: Only AfD can save Germany

quoted.text:
🇩🇪 GERMANY’S UNDER-60s GO AFD - BOOMERS STILL HOLD THE LINE

AfD is now polling at 26%, ahead of the center-right party CDU (24.5%) and absolutely steamrolling the left partySPD (15%), who may need a GPS to find relevance.

Under-60s? All in on AfD. From frustrated Gen Z to eye-rolling mid-career professionals, the message is clear: the old establishment’s playlist is on skip.

Even 18–29 year olds are leaning AfD, edging out the CDU and nearly tying Die Linke, yes, the far-left. Apparently, irony is alive and well.

The only demographic not buying in? Boomers. The last loyalists to the era of stability, newspapers, and actual phone calls.

One analyst put it best: “A few years ago, this was unthinkable. Now? It’s an unstoppable rise.”

Source: IPSA, La Gaceta, @Alice_Weidel
